awarespage.title: Aware Social Network
awarespage.description: The full-stack AWARE application offers features such as infinite loading, authentication, DMs, user tagging, tracking trending hashtags, bookmarking, and more.
awarespage.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
awarespage.whyWasItCreatedDesc: This is my largest project – a full-stack application built on Next.js. Users must first log in or register, with the option to sign in via Google. Authentication is handled by Lucia. Form validation is real-time thanks to the React Hook Form library. For the feed, I used React Query, which allows efficient data fetching, caching, and data revalidation as needed. React Query also implements infinite loading and optimistic updates, meaning actions like liking or following a user immediately reflect on the client before the request is sent to the database. The application supports creating posts with images or videos (with file size limits), uploaded via the UploadThing library, including drag-and-drop functionality for easier file uploads. Posts can be commented on through a fully functional commenting system. Searching is possible using hashtags (#example) or mentions (@example). Trending hashtags are cached every 3 hours. Users can edit their profile page, change their profile picture (with cropping options within the app), and update their bio. Notifications are also implemented – users are informed about new followers, likes on their posts, mentions, or incoming messages. The app includes a DM system integrated via a third party, Stream, offering features like group chats, file uploads, message reactions, and more. I also set up a cron job that automatically deletes unused uploaded files every 24 hours (e.g., when a user uploads an image for a post but doesn't submit the post). The latest feature added is the reposting option.
awarespage.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: Next.js 15, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
features.func3: React Query for efficient data fetching
features.func4: Optimistic updates for smooth user experience
features.func14: Postgres DB configuration with Prisma ORM

artstore.title: Art(Raven) Store
artstore.description: An e-commerce platform focused on selling paintings, clothing, AI-generated images, and other merchandise. Authentication, payment processing, and data storage are built on WixClient.
artstore.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
artstore.whyWasItCreatedDesc: I created this application because I enjoyed working on full-stack projects while developing AWARE and wanted to replicate that process. The application is built on Wix Studio for the backend, making it much easier to add and manage products. I can easily add attributes like color, size, and more, or delete products. The app also supports searching products by price (max/min) or category, which I wanted to try implementing. Note: If the login, checkout, or some items in the store aren't working, it's because I don't have an active Wix subscription.
artstore.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: Next.js 15, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS
features.func2: React Query for caching, optimistic updates, and infinite list loading
features.func3: URL state management for searching and filtering using useOptimistic
features.func4: Optimistic updates for smooth user experience
features.func5: Product options, variants, and inventory management
features.func6: Real-time form validation with React Hook Form & Zod
features.func8: Dark mode, light mode, and system mode

neuralnetwork.title: Neural Network Visualizer
neuralnetwork.description: This application serves as a tool for visualizing and testing neural networks. I created it using Vite, React, and OpenAI's new model – GPT-o1.
neuralnetwork.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
neuralnetwork.whyWasItCreatedDesc: This application was created as an experiment to explore what OpenAI can do. Although it's not the ideal approach for learning programming, I deliberately chose a complex topic – neural networks – to balance the use of AI while learning something new. After gaining inspiration from various online sources, I developed a neural network visualizer. I wrote almost no code for this project; most of the work was handled by OpenAI's model. However, this doesn't mean it was easy. I initially started the project in Next.js, but due to compatibility issues with some libraries like react-latex and react-mathjax, I had to switch to Vite. Even with the --legacy-peer-deps flag and forcing the installation, I couldn't get these libraries to work in Next.js 15. Nevertheless, this project helped me better understand how neural networks function and their role in machine learning and artificial intelligence.
neuralnetwork.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: React.js, Vite, Tailwind CSS
features.func2: Simple explanation of how neural networks work

nebulatrails.title: Nebula Trails
nebulatrails.description: The project started as a simple landing page. Gradually, I learned to convert files from .js, .html, .css to .jsx and .tsx. Finally, I added Stripe payment integration.
nebulatrails.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
nebulatrails.whyWasItCreatedDesc: This website was originally created in React using .js, .html, and .css files. Later, when I discovered the .jsx format, I decided to overhaul the project. Once I started working with TypeScript, I recreated the application in Next.js using the .tsx format. Gradually, I added more features to the application, such as Czech language support using the i18n library and Stripe payment options for individual cards. The app also includes a dark/light mode, which I hid because the main page background consists of images or videos, which could cause aesthetic and readability issues.
nebulatrails.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: Next.js 15, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS

sonicrun.title: Sonic Run
sonicrun.description: Sonic Run is a simple 1-button game created in JS using the Kaplay library. The goal is to achieve the highest score. The game gradually speeds up, increasing its difficulty.
sonicrun.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
sonicrun.whyWasItCreatedDesc: I created this application because I was inspired by childhood memories of playing simple browser games with friends during computer science classes or in after-school programs. I had already developed several web applications, but I wasn't keen on creating another typical website or landing page. I wanted to try something completely different, and I was always curious about how games are actually created. To my surprise, it was much simpler than I thought. I expected to deal with a lot of complicated functions, objects, etc., but thanks to the Kayplay library, it went smoothly. It was great to see my idea turn into a functioning game so quickly. This project reminded me how much I enjoy learning new things.
sonicrun.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

mtrx-mern.title: MTRX Social Network
mtrx-mern.description: A modern MERN stack application with Socket.io and Chakra UI support. It offers JWT authentication, post management, user following, theme switching, responsive design, and image chat.
mtrx-mern.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
mtrx-mern.whyWasItCreatedDesc: This application was created as my first ambitious project aimed at thoroughly understanding the collaboration between frontend and backend. During its development, I followed a detailed tutorial that helped me grasp the fundamental principles of full-stack development. The development took longer because I focused on mastering each part of the project and their integration. The application is built on React and Vite, with everything handled on the client side. Unfortunately, this causes issues like longer content loading times. The MongoDB database also has limitations – for example, when deleting a user, their comments remain in the database, which is a problem not addressed in this application. Nevertheless, the app includes functional basic features like liking, creating posts, and user login. I even implemented a simple chat application that allows sending messages to other users, but you need to specify the recipient's name accurately. Although the application has its limitations, it was an important step in my learning and practical acquisition of web development skills.
mtrx-mern.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: MongoDB + Express.js + React.js + Node.js + Socket.io + Chakra UI

store-mern.title: MERN Store
store-mern.description: A simple web application for managing products, allowing you to add, edit, and delete products. The application is built on the MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, and Node.js).
store-mern.whyWasItCreatedTitle: Why and How Was It Created?
store-mern.whyWasItCreatedDesc: This project was one of my first where I combined the backend with the frontend, teaching me how to work with the MongoDB database and set up its connection with the application. I wanted to improve my full-stack development skills, and this application was my first complete project of this kind.
store-mern.updateDesc: The application is constantly updated with new features and bug fixes.

features.func1: Tech Stack: React.js, Node.js, Express.js, MongoDB, Chakra UI
features.func3: Responsive UI with React.js and ChakraUI

weather-app.title: Weather Display Application
weather-app.description: A web application that allows you to display the weather in specified cities. The application is simple and uses a weather API.

netflix-clone.title: Netflix Clone
netflix-clone.description: A Netflix clone built with React, one of my first projects. Backend is on Firebase. Note: Authentication might not work as Firebase deactivates inactive databases after a while.

to-do.description: A To-Do application built with TypeScript, featuring functions for creating, editing, and deleting to-dos.
